文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk1
证据片段: Zircaloys (Zr-1.5Sn alloys with small additions of iron, chromium, and nickel)

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk1
证据片段: the coolant temperature increases from 204 to 282°C (399 to 540°F)

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk1
证据片段: Diffusion of iron in zirconium was reported to be extremely rapid at temperatures as low as 500°C

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk1
证据片段: The solubility of iron in zirconium at 820°C was reported to be 120 ppm

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk1
证据片段: autoclave exposure of samples to steam at 520°C was proposed

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk1
证据片段: the waterside oxide layer thickness increases uniformly from ~3μm (the preinstallation value) at the inlet end to a maximum of over 50μm near the peak neutron flux location

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk2
证据片段: in-flux oxidation rates are clearly enhanced (at a given temperature) relative to ex-reactor Zircaloy oxidation rates and to out-of-flux rates on actual pressure tubes

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk2
证据片段: in-flux oxidation rate varies exponentially with absolute temperature, similar to ex-reactor rates

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk2
证据片段: hydrogen content in the tube wall along the fueled region follows the axial distribution of the oxide thickness

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk2
证据片段: hydrogen content has a strong azimuthal distribution with the maximum occurring at the top of the tube, which is the lower temperature region

文献ID: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_003_chunk2
证据片段: hydrogen has a strong radial distribution with the maximum occurring at the tube inner surface, which is the oxidizing (hydrogen source) surface and which is at the lower temperature
